item.title: Sinosphere: ‘Dancing Granny’ Is Shot, but Don’t Expect the Music to Stop
item.description: The middle-aged dance enthusiasts who crowd sidewalks, parks and squares across China are the target of ire and, now, fire.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.media:description: Women dancing late at night near a residential compound in Beijing.

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: My Father’s Killer’s Funeral
item.description: Tens of thousands turned out in the streets of Pakistan to mourn the radical Islamist who assassinated my father.
item.dc:creator: AATISH TASEER

item.title: Angolan President, in Power Nearly Four Decades, Says He’ll Step Down
item.description: José Eduardo dos Santos, a former guerrilla who came to power in 1979, has been criticized for human rights violations and rampant inequality in Angola.
item.category: Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola
item.dc:creator: DIONNE SEARCEY

item.title: Obama and Canada’s Justin Trudeau Promote Ties and Climate Plan
item.description: The two leaders announced commitments to reduce planet-warming emissions of methane and pledged cooperation in preserving the Arctic.
item.dc:creator: JULIE HIRSCHFELD DAVIS and MICHAEL D. SHEAR
item.media:description: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau of Canada and President Obama at the arrival ceremony on the South Lawn of the White House on Thursday.

item.title: China’s Censors Denounced in Online Attack
item.description: A letter described as written by an employee of Xinhua, the main state-run news agency, spread quickly on the Internet. Then it was taken down.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: Chile Halts Inquiry on American Who Disappeared 31 Years Ago
item.description: A judge closed a case against retired police and military officers accused of abducting Boris Weisfeiler, who vanished in Chile during the Pinochet dictatorship, a mystery that may never be solved.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: PASCALE BONNEFOY
item.media:credit: Wendy Maeda/The Boston Globe, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Boris Weisfeiler, who disappeared in Chile in 1985.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Murdered for Activism in Honduras
item.description: In a country known to be deadly for rights advocates, my aunt stood up for the environment and her indigenous kin.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: SILVIO CARRILLO

item.title: Juba Journal: In South Sudan, City of Hope Is Now City of Fear
item.description: The Republic of South Sudan is not even five years old, but already 50,000 people have been killed in an ethnically driven civil war.
item.dc:creator: JEFFREY GETTLEMAN
item.media:description: Near Juba, the capital of South Sudan, 50,000 people live in a camp for internally displaced people opened after brutal ethnic fighting erupted two years ago.

item.title: Poland’s Government Is Accused of Violating Separation of Powers
item.description: A European watchdog group on Friday said Poland’s right-wing government had blunted the functions of the country’s constitutional court.
item.dc:creator: RICK LYMAN

item.title: Justin Trudeau’s White House Dinner Has the Air of a Family Reunion
item.description: The state dinner for Canada’s prime minister included celebrity guests born in his country, such as Ryan Reynolds, Sandra Oh, Michael J. Fox and Mike Myers.
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS FANDOS

item.title: Smugglers Prey on Migrants Desperate to Find Back Doors to Europe
item.description: With migrants starting to grow desperate, smugglers are fanning out in Greece, promising help and stoking European concerns about alternate routes.
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.dc:creator: LIZ ALDERMAN
item.media:description: A migrant camp in Greece at the border with Macedonia. More than 13,000 migrants have been stuck in the area after Macedonia sealed its border.

item.title: Op-Ed Columnist: Chappatte on Europe’s Deal With Turkey
item.description: European Union leaders and Turkey reached a tentative deal this week to help stem the flow of migrants to the Continent.
item.dc:creator: PATRICK CHAPPATTE

item.title: Pro-Democracy Nonprofit Is Banned in Russia
item.description: The prosecutor general’s office outlawed the National Democratic Institute, saying it posed “a threat to the foundations of Russia’s constitutional order and national security.”
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: IVAN NECHEPURENKO

item.title: The Saturday Profile: Once Hopeful for Harmony, a Philosopher Voices Discord in France
item.description: Alain Finkielkraut, arguably the country’s most visible public intellectual, feels that much of Islam is incompatible with French society.
item.dc:creator: ADAM NOSSITER
item.media:credit: Pierre Terdjman for The New York Times
item.media:description: The philosopher Alain Finkielkraut laments declining standards in French schools and the pernicious effects of multiculturalism.

item.title: Sinosphere: China’s Law on Nongovernmental Organizations Remains Work in Progress
item.description: There are questions as to if the government is reconsidering whether the legislation could crimp international cooperation in areas it cares about.
item.dc:creator: DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: Volunteers for Roots & Shoots, the Jane Goodall Institute’s youth program, planting tree saplings at a farm in Inner Mongolia in 2011 to help fight desertification.

item.title: As India Collaborates With Japan on Islands, It Looks to Check China
item.description: A bid to develop the Andaman and Nicobar chain signals a policy shift for India, which has not previously accepted offers of foreign investment on the archipelago.
item.dc:creator: ELLEN BARRY
item.media:description: Port Blair on South Andaman Island. There is a feeling in the town that the outside world, once distant, is drawing nearer.

item.title: He Abused Her for Years. She Shot Him. France Asks: Is It Self-Defense?
item.description: The case of Jacqueline Sauvage, who shot her husband after years of abuse, raises a difficult question for France: Are such killings self-defense?
item.dc:creator: LILIA BLAISE
item.media:description: Jacqueline Sauvage, right, with her lawyer in Blois, France, in December. Ms. Sauvage, who was convicted of killing her husband, has become a cause célèbre for those who want homicide laws changed to take into account killers who are victims of domestic abuse.

item.title: Mass Rape, a Weapon of War, Traumatizes South Sudan
item.description: A United Nations report says that sexual violence is part of wider efforts to punish and terrorize civilians in the civil war in South Sudan, with government-allied forces the worst offenders.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: NICK CUMMING-BRUCE
item.media:credit: Albert Gonzalez Farran/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The aftermath of an attack in February on a United Nations camp for civilians in Malakal, South Sudan.

item.title: Sinosphere: Donald Trump Criticized After Calling Tiananmen Protests a ‘Riot’
item.description: Mr. Trump said earlier comments to Playboy were not endorsing the crackdown, but critics said his response matched Beijing’s description of the events.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: Protesters calling for democracy and an end to corruption occupied Tiananmen Square in Beijing for six weeks until troops moved in the night of June 3-4, 1989, leaving hundreds, possibly thousands, dead.

item.title: Editorial: Fill In the Foreign Policy Blanks
item.description: Few of the candidates running for president have given American voters much of a sense of how they would take on issues like Syria and North Korea.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: THE EDITORIAL BOARD
